study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of ellagic acid (EA) in a novel liposomal formulation (EA-Hb/TAT&isoDGR-Lipo) for treating diabetic retinopathy (DR) by reducing oxidative stress, inhibiting angiogenesis, and ameliorating hypoxia.
results_summary: The study found that EA-Hb/TAT&isoDGR-Lipo protected retinal cells from high glucose-induced damage, inhibited VEGF-induced vascular endothelial cell migration and tube formation, and reduced hypoxia-related VEGF expression. It also improved retinal structure in a DR mouse model by downregulating GFAP, HIF-1α, VEGF, and p-VEGFR2.
population_specificity: Diabetic retinopathy mouse model

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the protective effects of Ellagic Acid (EA) against liver damage caused by cholestasis and to understand its underlying mechanisms in a bile duct ligation (BDL) rat model.
results_summary: EA significantly improved liver morpho-function, reduced liver enzyme levels (AST, ALT, ALP, GGT), and lowered inflammatory markers (TNF-α, TGF-β1) and fibrosis in BDL-induced rats. The study suggests EA's benefits may stem from its antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and anti-fibrotic properties.
population_specificity: Male adult rats subjected to bile duct ligation (BDL).
effective_dosage: 60 mg/kg body weight/day, administered by gavage.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the cellular mechanism by which ellagic acid exerts anti-inflammatory effects, particularly its role in inhibiting MEK1-ERK signaling and attenuating LPS-induced neuroinflammation, protein aggregation, and programmed cell deaths.
results_summary: Ellagic acid significantly inhibited LPS-induced ERK phosphorylation and neuroinflammation in BV-2 cells, attenuated LPS-induced ERK phosphorylation in vivo, and ameliorated LPS-induced reductions in M2 microglial biomarkers. It also abolished LPS-induced increases in pathological markers like α-synuclein trimer and active caspase 3.
population_specificity: BV-2 cells (in vitro) and animal models (in vivo) with LPS-induced neuroinflammation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the inhibitory effects, kinetics, and mechanism of Ellagic Acid (EA) on xanthine oxidase (XO), and to compare its activity with allopurinol.
results_summary: EA was found to be a reversible, mixed-type inhibitor of XO, though weaker than allopurinol. Fluorescence quenching and in silico analysis confirmed EA's interaction with XO, and in vivo experiments verified its anti-hyperuricemia effect.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vivo study details not provided in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-aging effects of Ellagic Acid (EA) on d-galactose-induced aging in rats, considering the influence of urolithin A-producing ability.
results_summary: EA improved cognitive impairment, hippocampal damage, and levels of GABA and 5-HT while reducing inflammation and oxidative stress in aging rats. The anti-aging effects were more pronounced in high-urolithin A-producing rats, and gut microbiota composition played a significant role in EA's efficacy.
population_specificity: Aging rats induced with d-galactose.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of ellagic acid on diabetic neuropathy in peripheral nerves using a rat model.
results_summary: Ellagic acid showed positive effects on nervous tissue in diabetic neuropathy, with treatment groups demonstrating reduced fibrinogen alpha uptake and laminin β-1 immunostaining similar to the control group. Axon numbers in treatment groups were similar to the control group, though some differences were not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Adult Wistar Albino rats with induced diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if SIRT1 and NRF2 mediate the protective effects of ellagic acid (EA) in aged kidneys.
results_summary: EA treatment significantly increased antioxidant enzymes, reduced oxidative stress, upregulated SIRT1 and NRF2 expression, and improved kidney function and histopathology in aged rats.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats (young: 4 months; old: 25 months)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether ellagic acid (EA) could prevent pulmonary and behavioral abnormalities induced by particulate matter (PM) exposure in mice.
results_summary: EA pretreatment significantly reduced PM-induced inflammatory and hypoxic gene expression in the lungs and prevented hyperactivity in mice. The effects were dose-dependent, with higher doses showing more pronounced benefits.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 mice (n = 8 per group).
effective_dosage: 20 mg/kg (low dose) and 100 mg/kg (high dose), orally administered.
study_duration: 14 days (EA pretreatment) with PM exposure during the last 7 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anticancer effects of ellagic acid on human colon cancer HCT-116 cells, focusing on its impact on long noncoding RNAs (lncRNAs).
results_summary: Ellagic acid inhibited proliferation, induced cell cycle arrest and apoptosis in HCT-116 cells, and altered the expression of 206 lncRNAs (115 down-regulated, 91 up-regulated). Co-expression network analysis suggested lncRNAs may be targets of ellagic acid's anticancer activity.
population_specificity: Human colon cancer HCT-116 cell line

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the inhibitory effects of Ellagic Acid (EA) and W. coagulans BC2000 on hyperlipidemia-induced cholesterol metabolism disorders.
results_summary: EA and W. coagulans BC2000 supplementation prevented hypercholesterolemia, promoted fecal cholesterol excretion, activated liver bile acid biosynthesis, and increased intestinal Eggerthellaceae abundance and liver EA metabolites.
population_specificity: C57BL/6J mice (n = 10 per group)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the oral bioavailability and bioactivity of ellagic acid and other polyphenols on cell modulators using computational methods.
results_summary: The study confirmed high bioavailability for certain polyphenols, including ellagic acid, but did not provide specific efficacy results for ellagic acid alone. Computational analysis suggested better bioavailability for free aglycones compared to esterified and glycosylated forms.
population_specificity: Not specified (computational study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Ellagic Acid on insulin resistance, oxidative stress, and sex hormone levels in women with polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS).
results_summary: Ellagic Acid supplementation significantly reduced fasting blood sugar, insulin resistance, cholesterol, triglycerides, inflammatory markers, and sex hormones while increasing total antioxidant capacity. No significant changes were observed in anthropometric factors, physical activity, or food intake.
population_specificity: Women with polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Ellagic Acid on glycemic indices, lipid profile, oxidative stress, and inflammation in type 2 diabetic patients.
results_summary: The study compared the effects of 180 mg/day of Ellagic Acid versus placebo over 8 weeks, measuring blood sugar, insulin, insulin resistance, and hemoglobin A1c, but the abstract does not provide specific outcome results.
population_specificity: Type 2 diabetic patients (n=44)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether ellagic acid and its metabolites could reduce lipid overload in Niemann Pick disease cells by enhancing extracellular vesicle secretion.
results_summary: Ellagic acid metabolites, urolithin A and B, increased extracellular vesicle secretion, reduced lipid accumulation, and improved lysosomal function in cultured macrophages and neurons from NPD mice. Oral ellagic acid treatment also lowered brain lipid levels and reduced microglia activation in NPD mice.
population_specificity: Cultured bone marrow-derived macrophages and neurons from ASMko and NPC1 mutant mice, which mimic Niemann Pick diseases types A and C.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether ellagic acid (EA) could alleviate neuropathic pain in rats induced by chronic constriction injury (CCI) and compare its effects to gabapentin.
results_summary: EA (50 or 100 mg/kg) reduced mechanical allodynia, cold allodynia, and thermal hyperalgesia in CCI-induced rats, comparable to gabapentin. EA also reversed elevated inflammatory and oxidative stress markers in the spinal cord.
population_specificity: Rats with CCI-induced neuropathic pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the potential benefits of ellagic acid supplementation in chronic diseases.
results_summary: The abstract highlights ellagic acid's anti-proliferative and anti-oxidant properties, suggesting potential health benefits, but does not provide specific outcomes or data.
population_specificity: Not specified (general chronic disease context implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the bioavailability and bioactivity of ellagic acid (EA) from pure dietary supplements versus natural sources (pomegranate juice).
results_summary: Plasma EA levels were similar between pomegranate juice and pure EA, but pomegranate juice increased urinary EA metabolites and acutely suppressed plasma MCP1, suggesting additional bioactive constituents in pomegranate juice influence EA metabolism.
population_specificity: Healthy volunteers
effective_dosage: 500 mg free EA (supplement) vs. 237 mL pomegranate juice (~120 mg EA)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the influence of Robuvit® (containing ellagic acid metabolites) on mood disorders, oxidative stress, fatigue, and insomnia in patients with high oxidative stress levels.
results_summary: Robuvit® supplementation significantly improved mood, reduced oxidative stress, and alleviated fatigue and insomnia, with no safety concerns reported. No changes were observed in the control group.
population_specificity: Forty patients with high oxidative stress levels, including 18 in the Robuvit® group and 22 in the control group.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether ellagic acid (EA) supplementation could mitigate high-sucrose diet-induced hepatic toxicity and metabolic dysregulation.
results_summary: EA supplementation improved dyslipidemia, restored glucose homeostasis, reduced hepatic ER stress and oxidative damage, and decreased visceral adipocyte hypertrophy and adipose tissue inflammation.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 male mice and human hepatoma cells.
effective_dosage: Equivalent to 0.03% of EA from raspberry seed flour.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of emollients in preventing atopic dermatitis (AD) in high-risk children.
results_summary: Six out of eleven randomized clinical trials showed no effect of emollients in preventing AD among neonates from high-risk groups, though emollients were noted to have a good safety profile and some potential benefits in predisposed populations.
population_specificity: Neonates and infants aged 1-4 years from atopic dermatitis risk groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the physiology of normal skin hydration, the mechanisms of dry skin, and the functional effects of basic emollients in managing xerosis cutis.
results_summary: The study found that basic emollients, formulated with humectants and occludents, effectively restore skin hydration and barrier function in xerosis cutis, regardless of underlying causes. They are recommended as the standard of care for long-term management of dry skin and associated diseases.
population_specificity: Individuals with xerosis cutis (dry skin) due to exogenous triggers, endogenous factors, genetic predisposition, or systemic diseases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether early skin emollient use (oil baths and facial cream) could prevent birch and grass pollen sensitization in infants, and whether the effect was mediated by skin barrier function or modified by birth season.
results_summary: The skin intervention alone increased the risk of birch sensitization, mediated by reduced skin barrier function in early infancy, while early food introduction had no effect on pollen sensitization risk. No significant effect modification by birth month was observed.
population_specificity: 2066 newborns in a population-based randomized controlled trial.
effective_dosage: Oil baths and facial cream from 2 weeks of age (specific amounts not detailed).
study_duration: Intervention duration not explicitly stated, but follow-up was until 3 years of age.

study_goal: To observe the effect of niacinamide-containing body emollients, alone or combined with a cleansing gel, on clinical symptoms, quality of life, and skin barrier function in adults with mild atopic dermatitis.
results_summary: Niacinamide-containing emollients significantly improved clinical symptoms, quality of life, and skin barrier function in mild AD patients. The addition of a niacinamide-containing cleansing gel further enhanced efficacy at certain time points.
population_specificity: Adults with mild atopic dermatitis.
effective_dosage: Not specified (emollients and cleansing gel used as topical treatments).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare parental satisfaction with different types of emollients (lotion, cream, gel, ointment) for treating childhood eczema.
results_summary: Lotions and gels had higher satisfaction scores than creams and ointments, with lotions being the most favored. Satisfaction scores correlated with emollient use and improvements in eczema severity.
population_specificity: Children aged 6 months to 12 years with eczema, recruited from primary care in England.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of inert emollients, moisturizers, and barrier preparations compared with standard care in preventing pressure injuries in aged care or hospital settings.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found no significant reduction in pressure injury incidence with emollients compared to standard care (relative risk 0.50, 95% CI: 0.15-1.63). One study using a combination of neutral body wash and emollient showed a significant reduction in stage one and two pressure injuries.
population_specificity: Aged care residents and hospital patients

study_goal: The researchers sought to determine how well adverse events are reported in randomized controlled trials (RCTs) of emollients for eczema.
results_summary: The study found that reporting of adverse events related to emollient use in eczema trials is poor and inconsistent, with 89% of studies collecting data but methods being poorly reported. Only two studies provided the questionnaires used for adverse event collection.
population_specificity: Adults or children with eczema.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical effectiveness and safety of four main emollient types (lotions, creams, gels, and ointments) for treating childhood eczema.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in eczema severity between the four emollient types over 16 weeks. Adverse events did not significantly differ between groups, though stinging was less common with ointments.
population_specificity: Children aged 6 months to 12 years with eczema (POEM score >2), predominantly White (86%).
effective_dosage: Initial prescription of 500 g or 500 mL, applied twice daily and as required.

study_goal: To evaluate whether the early use of emollients in infancy can prevent later development of atopic dermatitis (AD).
results_summary: The meta-analysis found no statistically significant difference in the incidence rate of AD between the experimental and control groups. However, variability in emollient use methods, follow-up times, and sample sizes prevented a definitive conclusion.
population_specificity: Infants at risk for or with early signs of atopic dermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and potential of 'emollients plus' in treating atopic dermatitis (AD) and their role in skin barrier restoration and maintenance.
results_summary: The study found that 'emollients plus' effectively restore and maintain skin barrier function across physical, biochemical, microbial, immunological, and neurosensory levels. They may also work synergistically with anti-inflammatory pharmacological therapies for AD treatment.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis (AD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether regular application of skin emollients in infants from a general population reduced the risk of food allergy.
results_summary: The study found no significant reduction in food allergy prevalence with emollient use compared to the no-intervention group (3.0% vs. 2.3%). The food intervention group showed a significant reduction, but emollients alone did not demonstrate efficacy.
population_specificity: Infants from a general population in Norway and Sweden, enrolled from birth.
effective_dosage: Bath additives and facial cream applied at least four times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether a promotora-led education program could improve adherence to topical emollients in Latin American pediatric patients with atopic dermatitis.
results_summary: The study found a trend toward increased adherence to emollients in the promotora group (43% vs. 20%), though not statistically significant (p = .09). Both groups showed improvements in AD knowledge and quality of life, but no significant differences between groups were observed.
population_specificity: Spanish-speaking caregivers of Latin American pediatric patients with moderate/severe atopic dermatitis in the U.S.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the removal of emollient residues from clothing through laundering and assess potential fire risks associated with residual paraffin-based and paraffin-free products.
results_summary: The study found that washing at 30, 40, or 60°C did not fully remove residues of high-paraffin emollients, particularly the 100% ointment, which also transferred to uncontaminated fabrics during washing. Residues persisted in the washing machine but did not cause secondary transfer in subsequent washes.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study using cotton fabric samples).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study focused on residue removal, not dosage).
study_duration: Single wash cycles at different temperatures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the clinical value of basic emollients for treating xerosis cutis in atopic dermatitis (AD).
results_summary: Most basic emollient formulations were found to be safe and effective at improving objective and subjective measures of xerosis cutis, with ongoing therapy preventing relapse and combination ingredients offering additive benefits.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis (AD) experiencing xerosis cutis (dry skin).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of prophylactic emollients initiated in early infancy for preventing atopic dermatitis (AD) and food allergy (FA).
results_summary: Prophylactic emollients did not significantly reduce AD overall but showed benefit in high-risk populations and when used continuously. No protective effects on FA were found.
population_specificity: Infants within the first 6 weeks of life, with a focus on high-risk populations for AD.
study_duration: Until AD assessment at 24 months of age (continuous use) or with intervals before assessment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of emollients in treating dry skin conditions and maintaining skin barrier function, as well as optimal nursing practices for emollient use.
results_summary: The study found that emollients promote skin health, prevent skin breakdown, and improve quality of life, but highlighted challenges such as product choice and regular application. It also outlined nursing best practices for prescribing and applying emollients.
population_specificity: Patients with dry skin conditions (specific population not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Vaseline jelly and a water-based formula on epidermal barrier function in psoriatic patients.
results_summary: Vaseline jelly reduced transepidermal water loss (TEWL) in psoriatic plaques, while the water-based formula increased stratum corneum hydration (SCH). Both emollients showed potential to improve epidermal barrier function in psoriatic patients.
population_specificity: Thirty-one plaque-type psoriasis patients and thirty-one healthy controls, matched by age and gender.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the epidermal barrier, its dysfunction, and the role of emollients in repairing skin hydration, particularly for conditions like atopic dermatitis.
results_summary: The abstract highlights emollients as a primary treatment for skin hydration issues, detailing their mechanisms, types, and considerations for use, but does not provide specific efficacy data.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion on skin hydration and emollients).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the cost-effectiveness of five different emollients (A, B, C, D, E) for treating atopic dermatitis in France, comparing their effectiveness in preventing flare-ups.
results_summary: Emollient A was the most effective, providing 3.89 years without flare-up (YWFU) over 5 years, but was more expensive than the least costly option (Emollient E). The incremental cost-effectiveness ratio for A compared to E was 5,877.48€/YWFU, indicating cost-effectiveness.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis in France (including children and adults).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the cost-effectiveness of different emollients (A, B, C, D) compared to no emollient use in managing atopic dermatitis (AD), focusing on time without flare-ups and quality-adjusted life-years (QALYs).
results_summary: Emollient A was found to be the most cost-effective strategy, generating 4.58 years without flare-ups over six years and dominating no treatment in both healthcare and societal cost perspectives. The incremental cost-effectiveness ratio (ICER) for emollient A compared to emollient B was £428.30 per additional year without flare-up.
population_specificity: Adult patients with atopic dermatitis (AD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the presence of potential contact haptens in emollients marketed for atopic skin care in Poland and Spain.
results_summary: The study found that a majority of emollients contained at least one potential contact hapten, with only a small fraction being hapten-free. Common haptens included phenoxyethanol, tocopherol, and undefined parfum.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients with atopic dermatitis (AD) in Poland and Spain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether daily use of lipid-rich emollients in infants could reduce the cumulative incidence of physician-diagnosed atopic dermatitis (AD) in a general population.
results_summary: The study is ongoing, but it is designed to measure the effectiveness of lipid-rich emollients in preventing AD in infants, with primary outcomes focusing on physician-diagnosed AD and secondary outcomes including caregiver-reported AD measures and development of other atopic diseases.
population_specificity: Infants recruited from primary care practices in Oregon, Colorado, Wisconsin, and North Carolina.
effective_dosage: Daily use of lipid-rich emollient (specific product or amount not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether daily emollient treatment during the maintenance period could reduce the risk of flares and improve symptoms in infants with moderate atopic dermatitis.
results_summary: The study found that emollient use significantly increased the cumulative maintenance rate (60.5% vs. 23.5%), prolonged the median time to flare (90 vs. 28 days), and improved EASI and IDQOL scores compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Children younger than 2 years with moderate atopic dermatitis.
effective_dosage: Not specified (emollients applied topically, frequency not detailed).
study_duration: 2-4 weeks of initial treatment, followed by a maintenance period (duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of four types of emollients (lotions, creams, gels, or ointments) in managing eczema symptoms in children over a 16-week period.
results_summary: The study evaluated emollients as part of standard care for eczema, measuring outcomes like symptom relief, treatment use, and quality of life, but specific efficacy results are not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Children aged 6 months to 12 years with mild-to-severe eczema and no known sensitivity to the study emollients.
effective_dosage: Apply twice daily and as required.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients in restoring skin barrier function and reducing corticosteroid use in patients with atopic dermatitis.
results_summary: The study found that systematic use of emollients helps restore skin barrier function and reduces the need for topical corticosteroids in infants, children, and adults with atopic dermatitis. Clinical trials and long-term experience support their efficacy and safety.
population_specificity: Infants, children, and adults with atopic dermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the rationale behind approved AD therapies, including emollients, and introduce novel promising drugs.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings about emollients' effects, only mentioning their inclusion in the review of AD therapies.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis (AD), varying by age groups and ethnicities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify the real-world use of emollients in moderate-to-severe atopic dermatitis (AD) and assess whether inadequate use contributes to disease severity.
results_summary: The study found that emollient use was fourfold lower than recommended guidelines, suggesting underuse may exacerbate AD. No significant efficacy was demonstrated, as the focus was on quantifying usage rather than measuring clinical outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with moderate-to-severe atopic dermatitis (n = 844), including juvenile (<16 years) and adult patients, with atopic comorbidities.
effective_dosage: Median use was 9.6 g per day (range 1.4-30.1 g).
study_duration: Prescribing was recorded over a 12-month period.

study_goal: To evaluate the effect of a cream containing topical PUFAs, humectants, and emollients on clinical signs of equine Culicoides hypersensitivity.
results_summary: The cream significantly improved skin lesions on treated areas but did not significantly reduce pruritus or improve coat quality. Overall condition improved, though five horses experienced adverse effects.
population_specificity: Privately owned horses (n=28) with clinical signs of Culicoides hypersensitivity.
study_duration: 8 weeks (4 weeks half-body treatment, 4 weeks full-body treatment)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the occlusion performance and visual/microscopic properties of two emollient gels (Isomol gel and Doublebase gel) against Vaseline.
results_summary: Doublebase gel (DBG) showed occlusion performance comparable to Vaseline and significantly better than Isomol gel (IMG), with DBG-treated skin losing less than half the weight of IMG-treated skin over 48 hours. DBG also maintained a smooth, uniform film and stable microstructure, while IMG phase-separated and had an inhomogeneous emulsion.
population_specificity: Ex vivo human skin samples from a single donor.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the short-term and long-term effects of two emollients on itching severity and skin barrier function in patients with xerotic eczema.
results_summary: Both emollients significantly reduced itching within 30 minutes of the first application, with maximum reductions of 63% and 69% by Day 14. Skin moisture and lipid content improved after the first application and continued to increase over 14 days of treatment.
population_specificity: Females and males with bilateral itching due to xerotic eczema.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the use of emollients and topical glucocorticoids in adolescents with eczema, focusing on treatment patterns and disease severity.
results_summary: Almost all adolescents with eczema used emollients, but only 55% reported using topical glucocorticoids. Treatment likelihood increased with current eczema symptoms but not necessarily with disease severity.
population_specificity: 3108 Swedish adolescents from the BAMSE birth cohort, including 247 clinically examined patients with current eczema.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if emollient acceptability in Atopic Dermatitis (AD) patients is influenced by clinical factors such as disease severity, quality of life, and product type.
results_summary: The study found that emollient usage is fundamental for AD treatment, with over 80% of patients finding them generally acceptable. However, aqueous cream was least acceptable, associated with lower skin hydration and poorer patient-reported acceptability.
population_specificity: 128 patients with Atopic Dermatitis (AD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of topical petrolatum, basis cream, glycerine, and olive oil on the transmission of ultraviolet A (UVA) radiation during PUVA therapy.
results_summary: White petrolatum significantly increased the minimal phototoxic dose (blocking effect), while basis cream, glycerine, and olive oil showed no significant effect. The study concluded that white petrolatum and basis cream should not be used before PUVA therapy, but glycerine and possibly olive oil could be considered.
population_specificity: 29 volunteers undergoing PUVA therapy.
effective_dosage: 0.3cc/25cm² of each agent applied before testing.
study_duration: Effects were measured 72 hours after application.

study_goal: To assess the effects of moisturisers (emollients) on eczema, including disease severity, satisfaction, flare prevention, and corticosteroid use.
results_summary: Moisturisers showed beneficial effects, such as reducing eczema severity, prolonging time to flare, and decreasing corticosteroid use, though minimal important differences were often unmet. Safety profiles were generally favorable, with no significant increase in adverse events compared to controls.
population_specificity: People with eczema (mean age: 18.6 years, 6603 participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an emollient containing Vitreoscilla filiformis biomass (LRP-VFB) could improve skin microbiota and reduce flare-ups in patients with atopic dermatitis compared to another emollient.
results_summary: The emollient with LRP-VFB significantly reduced SCORAD scores and flare-up severity compared to the control emollient, while also normalizing skin microbiota by reducing Staphylococcus genus levels and increasing Xanthomonas genus levels. These effects were more pronounced in patients experiencing relapse.
population_specificity: 60 patients with moderate atopic dermatitis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of emollients in managing eczema by comparing moisturizer use versus no moisturizer and assessing their impact on flare reduction and corticosteroid use.
results_summary: Emollients improved eczema symptoms (Scoring Atopic Dermatitis values) and reduced flare frequency and corticosteroid use, though the improvement did not meet the minimal clinically important difference. Some formulations (glycyrrhetinic acid-, urea-, and glycerol-containing creams) outperformed controls, but moisturizer alone led to more flares compared to combined use with fluticasone propionate.
population_specificity: 6,603 participants with eczema across 77 randomized controlled trials.

study_goal: To determine the skin barrier effects of commonly prescribed emollients (Doublebase™ gel and Diprobase® cream) in individuals with quiescent atopic dermatitis.
results_summary: Neither emollient significantly improved sustained skin barrier function, but both were safe and did not cause erythema. Diprobase® cream transiently improved permeability barrier function and hydration, while Doublebase™ gel provided a more sustained hydration effect.
population_specificity: Volunteers with quiescent atopic dermatitis (18 for Doublebase™ gel, 19 for Diprobase® cream).
effective_dosage: Two fingertip units applied twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of the skin microbiome in atopic dermatitis and assess the potential of emollients with antioxidant and antibacterial components to improve microbiome diversity.
results_summary: The study found that emollients containing antioxidant and antibacterial components may increase microbiome diversity in atopic skin, which is associated with improved atopic dermatitis outcomes. Worsening atopic dermatitis was strongly linked to reduced bacterial diversity.
population_specificity: Atopic dermatitis patients in Canada.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore parents'/carers' views on the effectiveness and acceptability of leave-on emollients for childhood eczema through qualitative analysis of interview data.
results_summary: Most participants in study 1 felt emollients improved eczema but had mixed views on long-term use, while all participants in study 2 (after using a web-based intervention) held positive views about long-term emollient use. Preferences varied regarding emollient thickness, with some finding thick ointments effective but difficult to use, and carers described a trial-and-error approach to selecting products.
population_specificity: Carers of children aged ≤5 years with eczema in southern England.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a Lactobacillus-containing emollient versus a normal emollient on atopic dermatitis (AD) symptoms.
results_summary: The Lactobacillus-containing emollient significantly improved skin permeability, reduced trans-epidermal water loss (TEWL), and lowered visual analogue scale (VAS) scores compared to the control emollient. Skin capacitance also increased significantly on treated sides.
population_specificity: 28 patients with atopic dermatitis (AD).
effective_dosage: Applied twice daily (specific amount not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review available evidence and provide recommendations to standardize and optimize the use of emollients in atopic dermatitis (AD).
results_summary: Emollients are effective as first-line therapy for AD, applied post-bathing, with multiple daily applications encouraged. They may act as steroid-sparing agents, but more studies are needed for definitive conclusions. Weekly application of 250-500g is currently recommended.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis (AD), including high-risk infants for primary prevention (though not yet recommended).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the role of emollients and keratolytics in the treatment of psoriasis, focusing on their efficacy and limitations.
results_summary: The study found that emollients and keratolytics are recommended as adjuvant therapy for psoriasis, particularly for descaling and penetration enhancement, but comprehensive trials are lacking except for combination products with salicylic acid and corticosteroids. Salicylic acid showed benefits in rapid onset and reducing severity but had limitations in certain patient groups.
population_specificity: Patients with psoriasis, including young children, those with renal/hepatic impairment, widespread psoriasis, undergoing phototherapy, or treated with calcipotriene/systemic salicylates.
interactions: Concomitant use with calcipotriene/systemic salicylates or phototherapy may pose limitations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the relationship between skin barrier integrity (measured by skin condition score) and bloodstream infection risk in preterm infants, and how emollients (sunflower seed oil and Aquaphor) affect this relationship.
results_summary: Emollients significantly slowed skin deterioration and reduced bloodstream infections in preterm infants, but only when applied before skin damage occurred. Both sunflower seed oil and Aquaphor showed similar protective effects.
population_specificity: Preterm infants (<33 weeks gestational age) in a hospital setting in Bangladesh.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of pressed ice plant juice (PIPJ)-based emollients versus petrolatum-based emollients on skin condition and barrier function in children with dry skin and atopic predisposition.
results_summary: Both emollient types improved skin condition, but PIPJ-based emollients showed superior stratum corneum hydration and lower transepidermal water loss compared to petrolatum-based emollients by week 16. Petrolatum-based emollients significantly reduced skin pH, while PIPJ-based emollients maintained stable pH levels.
population_specificity: Children aged 2-6 years with dry skin and atopic predisposition.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of wet-wrap treatment (WWT) with diluted corticosteroids versus emollients in children with severe atopic dermatitis (AD) over a 4-week proactive schedule.
results_summary: WWT with diluted corticosteroids was faster and more efficacious than WWT with emollients, showing significant improvement in objective SCORAD and quality-of-life index. Best results were observed in children aged 6-9 years and 0-3 years.
population_specificity: Children aged 6 months to 10 years with severe AD (objective SCORAD ≥40 ± 5).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of non-drug emollients (e.g., colloidal oatmeal, petrolatum, and prescription moisturizers) as alternatives to long-term use of topical corticosteroids (TCS) and topical calcineurin inhibitors (TCIs) for inflammatory skin conditions.
results_summary: The study found that emollients demonstrated efficacy in skin barrier repair and symptom relief with minimal complications, making them safe and effective alternatives to limit long-term use of TCS or TCIs. These non-drug options showed anti-inflammatory and barrier repair properties suitable for indefinite use.
population_specificity: Patients with steroid-responsive inflammatory skin conditions such as psoriasis and atopic dermatitis (AD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of topical emollients (4% urea lotion and liquid petrolatum) in treating PUVA-induced pruritus.
results_summary: Both 4% urea lotion and liquid petrolatum were remarkably successful in reducing pruritus, with statistically significant improvements (p < 0.0001). No significant difference was found between the two treatments (p = 0.753).
population_specificity: 41 patients over 18 years of age receiving PUVA treatment in a phototherapy unit.
effective_dosage: 4% urea lotion and liquid petrolatum (frequency not specified).
study_duration: 2 weeks of topical emollient use alongside PUVA treatment, followed by 2 weeks of PUVA alone.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review current data and practice to support professionals in using emollient therapies for dry-skin conditions.
results_summary: The abstract indicates that emollients play an important role in treating dermatological conditions, but current UK guidelines are limited. The study convened clinical professionals to address this gap.
population_specificity: Not specified (general dermatological conditions, with mention of childhood eczema).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to address the lack of nurse training in dermatology, focusing on the role and clinical use of emollient therapy.
results_summary: The abstract outlines the physiology of the skin and the role of emollient therapy but does not provide specific results on its effects.
population_specificity: Nurses with inadequate dermatology training.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop national care pathways for children with eczema, focusing on improving equity of care and defining competences for effective management.
results_summary: The study emphasized holistic eczema management, including skin care, infection treatment, and allergy trigger assessment. It highlighted the importance of patient and family education for treatment concordance.
population_specificity: Children with eczema.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide an overview of emollient therapy for dry skin in older individuals, emphasizing best practices, education, and its role as first-line treatment.
results_summary: The study highlights the importance of emollient therapy for managing dry skin in older adults, stressing proper choice, application, and education for patients, carers, and healthcare professionals. It advocates for skin care assessment as a priority and positions emollients as the primary treatment for dry skin.
population_specificity: Older individuals with dry skin.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of potent local steroids (betamethasone) versus emollient creams (Essex® and Canoderm®) in reducing acute radiation dermatitis in breast cancer patients undergoing adjuvant radiotherapy.
results_summary: The study found that betamethasone cream was more effective than emollients in reducing radiation dermatitis, particularly in specific subgroups (mastectomy patients, those receiving RT to the armpit/supraclavicular fossa, and Fitzpatrick skin type 1 patients). However, patient-reported symptoms did not differ between treatment groups.
population_specificity: Breast cancer patients who underwent mastectomy or breast-conserving surgery and were receiving adjuvant 3-D planned radiotherapy.
effective_dosage: Not specified (applied during and two weeks post-RT).
study_duration: 5 weeks during RT plus 2 weeks post-RT (total 7 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to discuss factors nurses should consider when advising patients on emollient selection to improve treatment adherence and outcomes.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that emollient therapy can reduce incidences of dry skin conditions like pruritus, ichthyosis vulgaris, eczema, and psoriasis, improving quality of life. However, choosing an effective emollient remains challenging due to the wide market variety.
population_specificity: Patients with dry skin conditions (e.g., pruritus, ichthyosis vulgaris, eczema, psoriasis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of emollients in maintaining skin barrier function and addressing contemporary issues in emollient therapy for eczema.
results_summary: The abstract highlights the widespread acceptance of emollients for eczema treatment but notes a lack of high-quality evidence on their effectiveness or comparative superiority. It also identifies issues with incorrect usage and inconsistent advice from health professionals.
population_specificity: Patients with eczema, particularly in the UK.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate adult atopic dermatitis (AD) patients' perceptions of the effectiveness of emollients, specifically heparinoid mucopolysaccharide creams or lotions, in managing dry skin, pruritus, and eczematous skin.
results_summary: The study found a strong correlation between patients' perceived efficacy of emollients and improvements in dry skin, pruritus, and eczematous skin, with greater efficacy reported in milder AD cases. Older patients and those with later onset AD reported higher efficacy for pruritus relief compared to younger or earlier onset patients.
population_specificity: 110 adult patients with atopic dermatitis (103 completed the study).
study_duration: Questionnaires were administered within 1 month of treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients in managing atopic eczema by improving skin hydration and treatment adherence.
results_summary: The study found that emollients effectively increase stratum corneum hydration and that continual therapy in combination with patient education enhances treatment compliance and beneficial effects.
population_specificity: Schoolchildren (15-20% affected) and adults (2-10% affected) with atopic eczema.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cost-effectiveness of topical emollients (sunflower seed oil and synthetic Aquaphor) in preventing mortality among hospitalized preterm infants in Bangladesh.
results_summary: Both sunflower seed oil and Aquaphor were highly cost-effective, reducing neonatal mortality by 26% and 32%, respectively. SSO was more cost-effective per death and year of life lost averted compared to Aquaphor, though Aquaphor showed incremental benefits in YLLs averted.
population_specificity: Hospitalized preterm infants (< 33 weeks gestation) in a tertiary hospital in Bangladesh.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether emollients or calcipotriol alter minimal erythema dose (MED) readings prior to narrowband UVB (NB-UVB) irradiation in healthy subjects.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in MED readings between control and any topical emollient or calcipotriol when applied 30 minutes prior to testing, suggesting they do not affect UV transmission if applied at least 30 minutes before treatment.
population_specificity: 20 healthy volunteers
effective_dosage: Not specified (various emollients and calcipotriol ointment/cream applied topically)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the role of emollients in reducing dry skin conditions and maintaining healthy skin by examining their interactions within the epidermis.
results_summary: The study found that emollients are essential for managing dry skin and maintaining skin barrier function, with effectiveness varying based on skin location, age, and patient preference.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of emollient use).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients, moisturizers, and keratolytic agents in the topical treatment of psoriasis, focusing on their supportive effects in normalizing skin function and reducing inflammation.
results_summary: The study found that emollients and moisturizers help normalize hyperproliferation, differentiation, and apoptosis, improve barrier function, and reduce Koebner phenomena. Keratolytic agents like salicylic acid and high-concentration urea are effective in the initial phase, while moisturizers and emollients are suitable for intermediate and chronic/remission phases.
population_specificity: Patients with psoriasis (specific demographics not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding emollients to standard topical corticosteroid therapy improves outcomes in children with atopic dermatitis.
results_summary: The study found that emollients significantly improved xerosis and pruritus during corticosteroid treatment and helped maintain clinical improvement after therapy discontinuation, with group B (emollient users) showing better long-term results than group A.
population_specificity: 52 children aged 2-12 years with atopic dermatitis.
effective_dosage: Emollients were used alongside 0.1% methylprednisolone aceponate cream once daily.
study_duration: 2 weeks of active treatment, followed by 4 weeks of observation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to increase nurses' knowledge about the choice and mechanisms of topical emollient therapy, particularly for eczema treatment.
results_summary: The abstract emphasizes the importance of emollients in treating dry skin conditions and provides practical tips for their application, but does not present specific clinical results or data.
population_specificity: Nurses, particularly non-medical prescribers, and patients with eczema or dry skin conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review skin barrier function, hydration, factors causing dry skin, and issues surrounding emollient use.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that emollients are the main therapeutic approach for dry skin but notes challenges in product selection and lack of appreciation for their importance. It does not provide specific efficacy results.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion on dry skin patients).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of emollients in managing diseases with dry skin as a major symptom and to identify the components of an ideal emollient.
results_summary: The study found that emollients play a significant role in improving skin condition and reducing pruritus in conditions like atopic dermatitis and psoriasis, alongside pharmacological treatments. They also emphasized the importance of selecting emollients that support proper epidermal differentiation.
population_specificity: Patients with dry skin conditions, including atopic dermatitis and psoriasis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the clinical contribution of bath emollients in treating atopic eczema, particularly their cost-effectiveness and role in treatment.
results_summary: The abstract highlights the significant NHS expenditure on bath emollients for eczema treatment but does not provide conclusive evidence on their clinical efficacy. It raises a question about their contribution without presenting specific outcomes.
population_specificity: People with atopic eczema, particularly preschool children.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess oil-massage practices and the acceptability of skin barrier-enhancing emollients (sunflower seed oil and Aquaphor) in preterm Bangladeshi neonates compared to usual care.
results_summary: The study found that topical therapy with sunflower seed oil or Aquaphor was perceived as superior to mustard oil by many families, with 42% of mothers reporting the hospital-applied emollient was better than home treatments. No adverse effects were reported from emollient use in the hospital.
population_specificity: Preterm infants (<33 weeks gestational age) in Bangladesh.
effective_dosage: Not specified (applied 1-6 times before admission, mean 2.2 times).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the clinical evidence for a new generation of emollients, specifically Dardia Lipo Line, in managing dry and sensitive skin, particularly post-therapy preventive skin care.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that emollients are effective in hydrating and replenishing lipids in dry or sensitive skin, with minimal risk of irritation or sensitization. The Dardia Lipo Line is formulated for post-therapy skin care, though specific clinical results are not detailed.
population_specificity: Patients with dry skin disorders (e.g., atopy, allergy, eczema, psoriasis) or dryness following chemotherapy or radiotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the indications, advantages, and disadvantages of wet-wrap treatment (WWT) for atopic dermatitis (AD), including its role alongside emollients in the maintenance phase.
results_summary: WWT combined with diluted steroids is effective for severe or refractory AD, reducing inflammation and itch, but requires careful monitoring due to risks like increased steroid absorption and infections. Emollients alone can be used in the maintenance phase to mitigate risks.
population_specificity: Children and adults with severe and/or refractory atopic dermatitis.
effective_dosage: Steroid dilutions of 5-10% were used in WWT; emollients were used without specified dosage.
study_duration: Not specified for emollients; WWT was recommended as short-term therapy for adolescents.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of various topical emollients (petrolatum, basis cream, glycerine, olive oil) on UVB transmission and their suitability for use before phototherapy.
results_summary: White petrolatum and basis cream increased minimal erythema dose (MED), indicating UVB blocking effects, while glycerine and olive oil had no effect on MED. The study concluded that petrolatum and basis cream should not be used before UVB therapy, but glycerine and olive oil are acceptable.
population_specificity: 32 volunteers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the cost-utility of pimecrolimus compared to conventional treatments (TCS and emollients) for mild to moderate atopic eczema.
results_summary: The study found that TCS dominated pimecrolimus in cost-utility, being both cheaper and more effective, though the differences in benefits were small. Pimecrolimus was only cost-effective compared to emollient alone at a specific willingness-to-pay threshold.
population_specificity: Children and adults with mild to moderate atopic eczema, with separate analyses for facial and body eczema.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding emollients to a propanol-based hand rub reduces skin dryness and erythema under frequent-use conditions.
results_summary: The study found that the hand rub with emollients significantly reduced erythema and dryness compared to the formulation without emollients, with no significant difference between atopic and non-atopic subjects.
population_specificity: 35 subjects, approximately half with atopic predisposition (modified Erlanger atopy score ≥8).
effective_dosage: 0.7 ml applied twice daily (0.81% w/w emollient mixture).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the UV transmission properties of 30 emollients and survey UK phototherapy units on their practices regarding emollient use before and after phototherapy.
results_summary: The study found significant variability in UV protection factors among emollients, with many blocking sufficient UV to potentially affect therapy outcomes. Survey results showed that 30% of phototherapy centers routinely used emollients before treatment, while 79% recommended their use after treatment.
population_specificity: Patients with psoriasis undergoing or about to undergo UV phototherapy and photochemotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical improvement in psoriasis between PUVA therapy combined with topical corticosteroids versus PUVA therapy combined with bland emollients.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in clinical improvement between the two treatments, with 95% clearance in the corticosteroid group and 80% in the emollient group. Median exposures and cumulative doses were similar between groups.
population_specificity: 40 patients with chronic plaque-type psoriasis.
study_duration: Not specified (PUVA therapy was given thrice weekly until clearance).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether topical application of emollients (sunflower seed oil or Aquaphor) could enhance skin barrier function and prevent nosocomial infections in very low birthweight premature infants.
results_summary: Sunflower seed oil reduced nosocomial infections by 41% compared to controls (p=0.032), while Aquaphor did not show a significant reduction (p=0.065). No adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Very low birthweight premature infants born before week 33 of gestation in a hospital setting in Bangladesh.
effective_dosage: Daily massage with sunflower seed oil or Aquaphor.
study_duration: Duration of hospital stay (exact length not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the importance of emollients in rehydrating dry skin and the need for nurses to understand their properties and effective use.
results_summary: The abstract states that emollients are the mainstay of treatment for dry skin in infants and young people, emphasizing their role in rehydration and the need for proper knowledge among healthcare providers.
population_specificity: Infants and young people with dry skin conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients and moisturizers in managing skin barrier disorders and dryness, focusing on their efficacy, safety, and patient acceptance.
results_summary: Emollients and moisturizers can improve skin barrier function and clinical appearance, with specific formulations like petrolatum and ceramide-dominant mixtures showing positive effects. However, some ingredients (e.g., emulsifiers) may weaken the barrier, and sensory reactions (e.g., from lactic acid or urea) may reduce patient compliance.
population_specificity: Patients with skin barrier disorders such as atopic dermatitis, psoriasis, ichthyosis, and contact dermatitis, including children in some studies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to propose guidelines for emollient therapy in eczema care to improve patient and health professional practices.
results_summary: The study highlighted variability in emollient prescribing practices and patient confusion, proposing standardized guidelines to promote effective use and consistent practices.
population_specificity: Patients with eczema and other dry skin conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the structure, function, clinical applications, and potential side effects of emollients in dermatological treatments.
results_summary: Emollients improve stratum corneum hydration, exhibit anti-inflammatory activity, and provide transient relief from irritation. They are effective in treating various dermatoses but can cause side effects like irritant dermatitis and allergic reactions.
population_specificity: Patients with dermatological conditions such as ichthyoses, xeroderma, atopic dermatitis, psoriasis, and photodamaged skin.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize and quantify how emollients interact with UV light transmission during phototherapy or photochemotherapy.
results_summary: Two emollients significantly reduced UV light transmission, potentially interfering with therapy, while oils enhanced UV transmission. The study concluded that emollients can modify therapy outcomes by altering UV light transmission.
population_specificity: In vitro study (no human or animal subjects specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of GLA-containing emollients versus classical emollients on clinical benefits, cutaneous hydration, and TEWL in children with atopic dermatitis, and to assess the clinical relevance of conductance and TEWL measurements.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in cutaneous hydration with GLA-containing emollients compared to the control group, but no statistically significant differences in TEWL or clinical scores. Two children in the non-GLA group developed eczematous lesions, while none in the GLA groups did.
population_specificity: 23 children with atopic dermatitis.
effective_dosage: Not specified (three GLA-containing emollients with different concentrations were tested).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of barrier creams or emollients in preventing work-related hand eczema in real workplace settings.
results_summary: The study found limited real-world intervention studies on emollients, with small sample sizes and short follow-up periods. The observed effects were influenced by confounding variables, and the study design faced challenges such as lack of blinding and undefined outcome parameters.
population_specificity: Employees in workplace settings, specifically mentioned in the context of nursing home employees.
study_duration: Relatively short follow-up (exact duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the ultraviolet protection factors of prescription emollients for UVB phototherapy and psoralen photochemotherapy.
results_summary: Of the 40 emollients tested, 55% had a UVB erythema protection factor >1.2 at 2 microliters/cm², and 78% at 4 microliters/cm². Fewer products (25% at 2 microliters/cm², 50% at 4 microliters/cm²) showed similar protection for psoralen erythema.
population_specificity: In vitro study (no human subjects specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an antiperspirant with emollient additives could reduce friction blisters, hot spots, and irritant dermatitis compared to emollients alone or no treatment.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in sweat accumulation, blister incidence, hot spot incidence, or blister severity between the antiperspirant with emollients, emollients alone, and no treatment. Irritant dermatitis was not reported in any condition.
population_specificity: 23 healthy men
effective_dosage: Not specified (emollient additives alone as placebo, antiperspirant with 20% aluminum zirconium tetrachlorohydrex glycine plus emollients)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding water-in-oil emollients to a topical corticosteroid regimen improves efficacy in treating chronic plaque-type psoriasis.
results_summary: The study found that combining water-in-oil emollients with betamethasone dipropionate cream once daily was as effective as twice-daily corticosteroid application alone and significantly better than once-daily corticosteroid alone. Emollients provided a steroid-sparing effect.
population_specificity: 96 patients with chronic plaque-type psoriasis.
effective_dosage: Once daily application of betamethasone dipropionate cream plus either a water-in-oil cream or lotion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of pH-stabilized creams, ointments, and non-alkaline soaps in treating chronic toxic contact eczema among trainee hairdressers.
results_summary: Regular use of pH-stabilized creams and ointments, along with non-alkaline soaps, led to clear improvement in eczematous changes in 70% of participants, reducing the need for cortisone ointments. However, 30% of participants were deemed unfit to continue as hairdressers despite treatment.
population_specificity: Trainee hairdressers with marked chronic toxic contact eczema (n=144).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and limitations of emollients in managing atopic dermatitis (AD) and explore hydrogels as a promising alternative.
results_summary: Emollients are effective for skin hydration in AD but suffer from poor patient compliance and risks like skin thinning and immunosuppression in severe cases; hydrogels show potential as an alternative due to better hydration, reduced side effects, and improved compliance.
population_specificity: Individuals with atopic dermatitis (AD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of various emollients in absorbing and filtering UVB radiation (280-315 nm) to determine their potential interference with the therapeutic effects of UVB in Goeckerman treatment for psoriasis.
results_summary: Planter's Peanut Oil and Mazola Corn Oil had no effect on UVB absorption, while Alpha Keri Bath Oil, mineral oil, and Johnson's Baby Oil showed minimal effects. Vaseline Petroleum Jelly, petrolatum, and hydrophilic ointment substantially reduced UVB-induced erythema, suggesting they may interfere with low-dose UVB therapy in psoriasis treatment.
population_specificity: Patients with psoriasis undergoing Goeckerman treatment (implied, not explicitly stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify acne-related issues in transgender patients undergoing hormone therapy and propose suitable dermatological care, including the use of ceramide-enriched emollients.
results_summary: The study found that ceramide-enriched emollients are mandatory for managing skin dryness and irritation in transgender patients, particularly those on feminizing hormones, but did not quantify their efficacy.
population_specificity: Transgender patients (transmen and transwomen) undergoing hormone therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of emollients in reducing the risk of invasive infection in preterm newborns compared to routine skin care.
results_summary: Emollients in preterm newborns reduced the risk of invasive infection compared to routine skin care, though more randomized trial evidence is needed to establish their effectiveness in LMICs.
population_specificity: Preterm newborns in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the evidence on the benefits and adverse effects of moisturizers in dermatitis and propose moderation in their clinical use.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that while moisturizers are part of dermatologic guidelines for dermatitis, occlusion from moisturizers may foster microbial dysbiosis and increase itch in some patients. The study proposes moderation in their clinical use.
population_specificity: Patients with dermatitis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the clinical outcomes of educational and psychological interventions, including emollients as part of standard care, for treating atopic dermatitis (eczema) in children and adults.
results_summary: The study found that group education interventions probably reduce clinical signs and symptoms of eczema in both short- and long-term, while individual education may reduce short-term signs. Technology-mediated education and other therapies showed some favorable effects, but clinical significance remains uncertain.
population_specificity: Children and adults with atopic dermatitis (eczema), primarily from high-income countries and outpatient settings.
study_duration: Varied by intervention (short-term: up to 16 weeks; long-term: more than 16 weeks)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the benefits and limitations of natural oils as emollients and occlusives, their role in wound healing and skin disease treatment, and their comparison to petroleum-based oils.
results_summary: The study highlights the moisturizing benefits of natural oils, their paradoxical effects on skin barrier function, and their potential utility in neonatal skin care, while also comparing them to conventional petroleum-based oils.
population_specificity: General and neonatal skin care (no specific demographic details provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients in managing atopic dermatitis (AD) and preventing flare-ups.
results_summary: The study found that regular emollient use is key in managing AD, alongside topical corticosteroids and calcineurin inhibitors, and can help prevent flare-ups. Wet wrap therapy was also noted to improve AD severity and extent.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis (AD) and seborrheic dermatitis (SD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the level of knowledge about baseline therapy (including emollient use) in atopic dermatitis between adults with AD and parents of children with AD.
results_summary: The study found that adults with AD had lesser knowledge about baseline therapy than parents of children with AD, with significant differences in understanding emollient principles and bathing rules. Both groups expressed a strong need for further education on these topics.
population_specificity: Adults with atopic dermatitis (n=180) and parents of children with AD (n=106).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare and rank the efficacy and safety of topical anti-inflammatory treatments, excluding emollients used alone, for eczema management.
results_summary: The study did not evaluate emollients as a standalone treatment, focusing instead on other topical anti-inflammatory agents like corticosteroids, calcineurin inhibitors, and JAK inhibitors.
population_specificity: Participants with eczema of any severity, predominantly from high-income countries and secondary care settings, including adults and some children (<12 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety profile and management strategies for talquetamab-associated adverse events, including the use of emollients for dermatologic toxicities.
results_summary: Emollients were used to manage skin and nail toxicities associated with talquetamab, with most adverse events being low grade and leading to few discontinuations. The study did not focus on emollients' efficacy or safety as a standalone treatment.
population_specificity: Patients with triple-class exposed relapsed/refractory multiple myeloma (RRMM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients as a co-treatment for lichen sclerosus (LS) alongside topical corticosteroids.
results_summary: The study found that emollients are recommended as a co-treatment for genital LS in both females and males, adults and children, alongside ultrapotent or potent topical corticosteroids. The abstract does not provide specific efficacy data for emollients alone.
population_specificity: Patients with lichen sclerosus (LS), including females and males, adults and children.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients as a co-treatment for lichen sclerosus (LS) alongside topical corticosteroids.
results_summary: The study found that emollients are recommended as a co-treatment for genital LS, supporting their use in conjunction with potent or ultrapotent topical corticosteroids. No specific adverse effects or limitations of emollients were mentioned.
population_specificity: Patients with lichen sclerosus (LS), including females and males, adults and children.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of two commercial veterinary emollients (MicroPearls and Humilac) in treating wintertime dry skin in dogs.
results_summary: MicroPearls was superior to Humilac in 80% of the dogs (16 out of 20), with rare side effects reported for either product. The study used a crossover design, switching treatments after 2 weeks to assess comparative efficacy.
population_specificity: Twenty dogs with wintertime dry skin.
effective_dosage: Weekly treatment according to manufacturers' recommendations (specific dosage not provided).
study_duration: 4 weeks (2 weeks per product in a crossover design).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize recent advances in phytochemical-based topical treatments for eczema, including emollients, and evaluate their efficacy and potential to mitigate side effects of conventional treatments.
results_summary: The study found that phytochemical-based treatments, including emollients, improved AD symptoms such as reduced SCORAD index, epidermal thickness, and transepidermal water loss, while also upregulating the FLG gene and reducing inflammatory markers. Various nanocarriers were noted to enhance the efficacy of these treatments.
population_specificity: Individuals with atopic dermatitis (AD) and AD mouse models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight severe dermatological toxicities associated with ATRA and the potential exacerbation by triazole antifungals, while noting the use of emollients for managing skin conditions.
results_summary: Emollients were used to prevent transdermal water loss in patients with exfoliative dermatitis, but the study primarily focused on the adverse effects of ATRA and triazole antifungals, not the efficacy of emollients.
population_specificity: Asian APL patients (ages 15, 28, and 33) with severe dermatological toxicities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review and update clinical guidelines for diagnosing and managing atopic dermatitis, including the role of nonpharmacologic therapies like emollients.
results_summary: The study emphasized the use of nonpharmacologic therapies, such as emollients, to restore the natural skin barrier as a first-line treatment for atopic dermatitis, alongside pharmacologic options for more severe cases. Evidence-based practices were prioritized over those lacking therapeutic data.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis (AD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop evidence- and consensus-based guidelines on the use of emollients and other treatments for atopic eczema, including their role in basic therapy.
results_summary: The guideline provides detailed recommendations on emollient use as part of basic therapy for atopic eczema, alongside other treatments like topical anti-inflammatory agents and UV phototherapy. It also covers patient education and specific considerations for pediatric, adolescent, and pregnant populations.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic eczema, including pediatric and adolescent patients, pregnant or breastfeeding women, and those planning to have children.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients alongside steroid-sparing alternatives in managing atopic dermatitis (AD).
results_summary: The study highlights the necessity of emollient use in AD management, emphasizing their role in improving disease severity alongside other topical therapies. Emollients are presented as a foundational component of AD treatment, though specific efficacy data are not detailed.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis (AD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of emollients in preventing food allergy by correcting skin barrier dysfunction and to identify characteristics of more effective interventions.
results_summary: Studies on emollient use from birth showed conflicting results, with meta-analyses indicating no effect or only slight positive effects on food allergy prevention. Successful trials tended to use emollients with an acidic pH of 5.5, applied over the entire body, and combined with topical corticosteroids in affected areas.
population_specificity: Infants from birth

study_goal: The study does not focus on emollients but evaluates the clinical and cost effectiveness of abrocitinib, tralokinumab, and upadacitinib for moderate-to-severe atopic dermatitis.
results_summary: The study does not report findings on emollients, as it primarily compares systemic therapies like abrocitinib, tralokinumab, and upadacitinib to existing treatments for atopic dermatitis.
population_specificity: Adolescents and adults with moderate-to-severe atopic dermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the role of emollients in the management of atopic dermatitis (AD) as part of traditional treatment options.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that emollients are traditionally used in AD management, alongside other treatments like topical corticosteroids and systemic therapies, but does not provide specific efficacy data for emollients alone. Newer biologic and small molecule drugs are noted as important for moderate-to-severe AD.
population_specificity: Pediatric and adult patients with atopic dermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether a mānuka oil-based emollient cream (2% ECMT-154) is a safe and effective topical treatment for moderate to severe eczema.
results_summary: The study is ongoing, with recruitment through community pharmacies starting in January 2022 and follow-up to be completed by mid-2023. Efficacy and acceptability data will be collected to determine if the emollient provides a novel treatment option for eczema.
population_specificity: Participants with moderate to severe eczema recruited from community pharmacies in Aotearoa New Zealand.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the challenges and effectiveness of emollients in managing atopic dermatitis (AD) in elderly patients, alongside other treatments like biologics and JAK inhibitors.
results_summary: The study found that elderly patients often struggle with regular use of emollients, leading to recurrent or worsened AD progression. While emollients are fundamental, their efficacy is limited without systematic medication approaches, and biologics like dupilumab show better outcomes for moderate to severe AD in this population.
population_specificity: Elderly patients with atopic dermatitis (AD).

study_goal: The study aimed to determine seropositivity to parasitic zoonoses (Echinococcus granulosus, Fasciola hepatica, Taenia solium cysticercus) and describe infected patients' characteristics in 13 Peruvian highland regions (2016–2019).
results_summary: The study found seropositivity rates of 7.9% for fascioliasis, 4.9% for cystic echinococcosis, and 2.3% for T. solium cysticercus, with regional variations. Sociodemographic factors, including vegetable consumption in emollients, influenced transmission.
population_specificity: Residents of 13 highland regions in Peru (2016–2019).

study_goal: To investigate the efficacy of a novel, multi-active emollient in preventing and managing acute radiation dermatitis (ARD) in breast cancer patients undergoing moderate hypofractionated radiotherapy compared to standard care.
results_summary: The novel emollient significantly reduced ARD severity, with 82% of patients in the experimental group experiencing grade 1 ARD and only 16% grade 2, compared to 50% grade 1 and 48% grade 2 or higher in the control group (P = .013).
population_specificity: Breast cancer patients undergoing moderate hypofractionated radiotherapy (40.05-55.86 Gy, 15-21 fractions).
effective_dosage: Applied twice daily during the complete radiotherapy course.
study_duration: Duration of the radiotherapy course (specific length not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness and acceptability of four types of emollients (lotion, cream, gel, ointment) for treating childhood eczema.
results_summary: The study found no difference in effectiveness among the four emollient types, with similar outcomes in eczema symptoms, severity, and quality of life. Satisfaction varied by type, with lotions and gels being most preferred, while ointments caused less stinging and required less frequent use.
population_specificity: Children aged 6 months to 12 years with eczema of at least mild severity, predominantly white (86.0%) and 46.4% female.
effective_dosage: Not specified (study emollients were used alongside usual care).
study_duration: 16 weeks (with secondary outcomes assessed over 52 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the association between bathing frequency and factors like emollient use in the first 9 weeks of life, as part of a broader study on atopic dermatitis (AD) prevention.
results_summary: The study found that moisturizer use was significantly associated with more frequent bathing (OR = 2.03). Other factors like ethnicity, parental education, geographic location, and pet ownership also influenced bathing frequency, which may be relevant for AD prevention studies.
population_specificity: 909 parent/newborn dyads from 25 pediatric and family medicine clinics across Oregon, North Carolina, Colorado, and Wisconsin.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze how moisturizers, including emollients, support the four functional layers of the skin barrier to promote homeostasis and repair.
results_summary: Moisturizers, including emollients, were shown to improve transepidermal water loss and strengthen the physical, chemical, microbiologic, and immunologic layers of the skin barrier through mechanisms like occlusion, hydration, and ceramide production.
population_specificity: Not specified (general skin barrier disruption, e.g., atopic dermatitis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the management of ichthyoses, including the role of emollients in symptomatic relief and scale reduction.
results_summary: The study highlights that emollients, along with keratolytics and retinoids, are used for symptomatic relief and scale reduction in ichthyosis, contributing to improved quality of life.
