Recent advances focus on pathogenesis-based targeted therapies, but emollients remain a foundational treatment.
population_specificity: Patients with ichthyoses, a group of rare genetic diseases characterized by hyperkeratosis and scaling.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe neonatal skin care practices in Africa and identify opportunities for evidence-based interventions to improve these practices, focusing on emollient use.
results_summary: The review found that emollients were used for perceived benefits such as thermal care, illness treatment, growth promotion, infection reduction, and skin improvement. Some studies reported quantitative health impacts, including improved skin condition, neurodevelopment, bone growth, and reduced nosocomial infections.
population_specificity: Newborn infants in Africa

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of paraffin-based and ceramide-based moisturizers in improving disease activity in children with mild to moderate atopic dermatitis (AD).
results_summary: Both paraffin-based and ceramide-based moisturizers showed comparable improvements in disease activity, quality of life, and transepidermal water loss, but statistical equivalence could not be conclusively proven due to confidence intervals exceeding predefined margins.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients (mean age 8.2 years) with mild to moderate AD and a mean disease duration of 60 months.

study_goal: To determine the effectiveness of different hand hygiene agents, including emollient-containing alcohol hand sanitiser, for preventing neonatal infection in community and health facility settings.
results_summary: The study found that 2% chlorhexidine gluconate (CHG) probably reduces the risk of all bacteriologically confirmed infections compared to 61% alcohol hand sanitiser (containing emollients), but there was little to no difference in skin effects on nurses between the two agents. The evidence was of moderate to very low certainty, and no meaningful conclusions could be drawn about the superiority of one agent over another.
population_specificity: Neonates, pregnant women, mothers, caregivers, and healthcare workers in community and health facility settings.
effective_dosage: 61% alcohol hand sanitiser (with emollients) – exact frequency not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients 'plus' and other therapies in managing atopic dermatitis by targeting skin microbiome dysbiosis and Staphylococcus aureus over-colonization.
results_summary: The study suggests that emollients 'plus' and other indirect therapies may help rebalance microbial diversity and reduce S. aureus over-colonization, potentially mitigating AD flares and improving skin barrier function.
population_specificity: Adults and children with atopic dermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate metronidazole-related cutaneous manifestations and the effectiveness of therapeutic interventions, including emollients, in managing these reactions.
results_summary: Emollients were among the therapeutic interventions used to ameliorate metronidazole-induced cutaneous manifestations, showing effectiveness when combined with other treatments like antihistamines and corticosteroids. The study did not isolate emollients' specific efficacy but included them as part of a broader supportive therapy.
population_specificity: Patients aged 16-78 years with metronidazole-related cutaneous adverse drug reactions (26 patients: 20 female, 6 male).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients in the treatment of atopic dermatitis (AD), focusing on symptom reduction and skin care.
results_summary: The abstract indicates that emollients are part of the treatment regimen for AD, alongside other therapies, but does not provide specific efficacy data for emollients alone.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis (AD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether Emollient 'plus' could reduce corticosteroid consumption in patients with mild to moderate atopic dermatitis while maintaining efficacy.
results_summary: The study found that Emollient 'plus' significantly reduced corticosteroid use in terms of quantity, frequency, and days of application compared to the control group, while maintaining similar efficacy and tolerability. Both groups showed comparable improvements in clinical evaluations and quality of life measures.
population_specificity: Patients with mild to moderate atopic dermatitis (SCORAD score 20-30), aged 3-71 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore barriers to treatment adherence in children and young people with atopic eczema and identify recommendations for practice.
results_summary: The study identified three key themes affecting adherence: relationships, medicines concerns, and information deficits. It recommended individualized education, understanding psychosocial effects, and providing clear advice to improve adherence.
population_specificity: Children and young people with atopic eczema.

study_goal: To compare the efficacy of an Emollient 'plus' balm and corresponding syndet versus usual commercial emollients and cleansers in improving skin barrier, microbiome, and symptoms in patients with moderate to severe AD receiving systemic treatment.
results_summary: The Emollient 'plus' regimen significantly reduced pruritus and improved some quality of life items compared to the control group, while using 23% less product over 10 weeks.
population_specificity: Patients with moderate to severe AD (SCORAD score ≥ 40) receiving systemic treatment (cyclosporin A, dupilumab, or a Janus kinase inhibitor).
effective_dosage: Twice daily application of Emollient 'plus' after pre-cleaning with the syndet.

study_goal: To provide evidence-based recommendations for the management of atopic dermatitis (AD) in adults using topical treatments, including emollients.
results_summary: The study strongly recommends the use of moisturizers (emollients) for managing AD, highlighting their effectiveness as part of the treatment regimen. No significant adverse effects were reported, supporting their safety and clinical utility.
population_specificity: Adults with atopic dermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the characteristics of participants who responded to treatment with TMB-001, a novel topical isotretinoin ointment formulation, for congenital ichthyosis.
results_summary: Participants with lower baseline body surface area (BSA) involvement and higher Dermatology Life Quality Index (DLQI) and Itch-Numeric Rating Scale (I-NRS) scores were more likely to achieve treatment success, as measured by VIIS-50 and IGA response. Higher DLQI and I-NRS scores at baseline were associated with better treatment outcomes.
population_specificity: Participants ≥ 9 years of age with genetically confirmed congenital ichthyosis and ≥ 2 Visual Index for Ichthyosis Severity (VIIS) assessment areas with ≥ 3 scaling score.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of TMB-001, a topical isotretinoin ointment, versus vehicle (emollient/keratolytic) in treating scaling in ARCI-LI and XLRI subtypes of congenital ichthyosis.
results_summary: TMB-001 showed greater efficacy than vehicle in achieving ≥50% reduction in scaling (VIIS 50) and ≥2-grade improvement in IGA scores, with varying response rates between ARCI-LI and XLRI subtypes. Most adverse events were mild application-site reactions.
population_specificity: Participants aged ≥9 years with genetically confirmed ARCI-LI or XLRI and moderate-to-severe scaling.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to update guidelines for managing atopic dermatitis in adults, evaluating the effectiveness and recommendations for topical therapies, including emollients.
results_summary: The study strongly recommended the use of nonprescription moisturizers (emollients) for atopic dermatitis, supported by systematic evidence. Conditional recommendations were made for bathing and wet wrap therapy, while topical antimicrobials, antiseptics, and antihistamines were advised against.
population_specificity: Adults with atopic dermatitis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize evidence-based guidelines for the use of emollients and other topical therapies in the management of psoriasis.
results_summary: The abstract indicates that emollients are included in the AAD and NPF guidelines as part of the recommended topical therapies for psoriasis, suggesting their utility in clinical practice. However, specific efficacy data for emollients alone are not detailed.
population_specificity: Patients with psoriasis (general, no specific subgroup mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Rilastil Difesa Sterile® cream versus a standard moisturizing cream in treating hand eczema in healthcare workers during the COVID-19 pandemic, considering both dermatological and psychological outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that both clinical (HECSI) and psychological scores decreased more in patients treated with Rilastil Difesa Sterile® cream compared to the control group, though the results did not reach statistical significance.
population_specificity: 51 healthcare workers suffering from hand eczema during the COVID-19 pandemic.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether daily emollient use in the first year of life prevents atopic dermatitis, food allergy, asthma, or hay fever by age 5.
results_summary: Daily emollient use did not prevent atopic dermatitis, food allergy, asthma, or hay fever by age 5, with no significant differences between the emollient and control groups. Parents reported more frequent moisturizer use in the emollient group, but clinical outcomes were similar.
population_specificity: Term infants with a family history of atopic disease.
effective_dosage: Daily emollient application (specific product or amount not detailed).
study_duration: First year of life, with follow-up to age 5.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the role of emollients in the conservative management of acquired ichthyosis (AI) as part of a broader therapeutic approach.
results_summary: The abstract indicates that emollients are part of the conservative therapies for AI, alongside keratolytics, retinoids, or corticosteroids, but does not provide specific efficacy data for emollients alone.
population_specificity: Patients with acquired ichthyosis (AI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients in treating cutaneous barrier dysfunction as part of the management strategy for atopic dermatitis.
results_summary: The study found that emollients are recommended as a primary measure to address cutaneous barrier dysfunction in atopic dermatitis, alongside other treatments like topical corticosteroids and avoidance of exacerbating factors. The guidelines emphasize their inclusion in a comprehensive treatment approach.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis (AD) in Japan.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess health care resource utilization and treatment patterns, including emollient use, in children and adolescents with moderate-to-severe atopic dermatitis.
results_summary: Emollients/moisturizers were used for a mean of 30.9 months, but the study noted small changes in quality of life, suggesting suboptimal disease control with current treatments.
population_specificity: Children (6-11 years) and adolescents (12-17 years) with moderate-to-severe atopic dermatitis in the UK.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the real-life effectiveness and safety of dupilumab (not emollients) in children aged 6-11 years with moderate-to-severe atopic dermatitis.
results_summary: Dupilumab significantly improved disease severity (EASI score), pruritus (P-NRS), sleep quality (S-NRS), and quality of life (c-DLQI) by week 16, with 74.54% achieving EASI75. The treatment showed a good safety profile.
population_specificity: Children aged 6-11 years with moderate-to-severe atopic dermatitis.
effective_dosage: 300 mg on day 1, followed by 300 mg on day 15, then 300 mg every 4 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients in treating cutaneous barrier dysfunction as part of the management strategy for atopic dermatitis.
results_summary: The study highlights emollients as a key component in managing atopic dermatitis by addressing cutaneous barrier dysfunction, alongside other treatments like topical corticosteroids and tacrolimus ointment. The guidelines emphasize their inclusion in a comprehensive treatment approach.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis (AD) in Japan.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of an intervention involving emollients and hand care products in preventing occupational hand eczema among healthcare workers during the COVID-19 pandemic.
results_summary: The intervention group showed no new cases of hand eczema, while the control group had 12 cases (8.8%). The intervention also improved skin care behavior, with higher daily use of emollients at work and home.
population_specificity: Healthcare workers (302 participants, with 135 in the intervention group and 167 in the control group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether existing systematic reviews addressed the use of emollients as an intervention for preterm or low birth weight infants.
results_summary: The study found that one systematic review fully addressed the research question on emollients, covering 121 studies and 25,465 preterm or LBW infants, and received a "high" AMSTAR quality rating. No specific outcomes or effects of emollients were detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Preterm or low birth weight infants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the adverse event of PUVA pricks and evaluate effective treatment options, including emollients, for managing this condition.
results_summary: The study found that petrolatum emollients are among the effective topical treatments for PUVA pricks, alongside capsaicin 8% cream and urea 4%. The abstract suggests these options help manage the paroxysmal pain episodes associated with PUVA therapy.
population_specificity: Patients treated with PUVA therapy who experienced PUVA pricks (33 patients from 9 articles).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide guidance on selecting appropriate moisturizers, including emollients, based on skin conditions and their role in improving skin barrier function and managing skin diseases.
results_summary: The study highlights that moisturizers, including emollients, improve skin dryness and barrier function, and are useful adjuvants in treating skin diseases like atopic dermatitis, contact dermatitis, psoriasis, acne, and rosacea. The choice of moisturizer should consider ingredients, effectiveness, safety, and patient-specific skin conditions.
population_specificity: Patients with various skin conditions (e.g., atopic dermatitis, contact dermatitis, psoriasis, acne, rosacea) and general skin dryness.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients in restoring skin barrier integrity and managing atopic dermatitis.
results_summary: The study found that regular use of emollients is a mainstay treatment for atopic dermatitis, effectively restoring skin barrier integrity and complementing topical anti-inflammatory therapies.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis (atopic eczema), including moderate to severe cases.

study_goal: To develop an online behavioral intervention to help parents/carers manage and co-manage their child's eczema, including the use of emollients and topical corticosteroids.
results_summary: Parents/carers had concerns about using emollients and TCS, lacked complete knowledge and skills for eczema management, and were reluctant to transition to co-managing eczema with their child. The intervention provided new information and techniques to address these barriers.
population_specificity: Parents/carers of children with eczema.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of emollient application compared to no emollient application in term or near-term healthy newborns, focusing on outcomes like neonatal mortality, systemic infections, atopic dermatitis, and skin condition.
results_summary: Emollient application showed little to no effect on atopic dermatitis in healthy term newborns but probably lowered the risk in 'at-risk' newborns. Effects on food allergy, allergic sensitization, skin dryness, and skin problems were uncertain.
population_specificity: Term or near-term healthy newborns, including those 'at risk' for developing atopy.
effective_dosage: Creams or nut, seed, and vegetable oils; frequency not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe longitudinal care pathways, including treatment patterns and disease progression, in patients with atopic dermatitis (AD), with a focus on commonly used treatments like emollients.
results_summary: Emollients were among the most frequently used treatments across all age cohorts for AD, alongside topical corticosteroids (TCSs). The study noted that healthcare contacts and AD-indicated treatments were concentrated in the year managed AD care was initiated but decreased significantly thereafter.
population_specificity: 341,866 patients with AD, including pediatric (<12 years), adolescent (12-<18 years), and adult (≥18 years) cohorts.
study_duration: Longitudinal observational study (specific duration not mentioned)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of various strategies, including emollients, in preventing or managing acneiform eruptions caused by EGFR inhibitor therapy.
results_summary: The study found that emollients were part of a general skin-care routine recommended alongside oral tetracycline antibiotics, but their standalone efficacy was not statistically assessed.
population_specificity: Adults with advanced lung, colorectal, or head and neck cancers receiving EGFR inhibitor therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of various treatments, including emollients, for keratosis pilaris rubra (KPR).
results_summary: The study found that emollients, along with other topical therapies, provided inconsistent benefits for KPR, with limited success compared to pulsed dye laser therapy or topical sirolimus.
population_specificity: 15-year-old boy with KPR (though broader context suggests general KPR patients).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the societal costs, healthcare resource utilization, and impact on work due to chronic hand eczema (CHE), including the costs associated with emollients.
results_summary: The study found that emollients cost $36.49 per month in Switzerland and $178.40 per year in Germany, with CHE leading to significant societal costs, including hospitalization and job loss. The review highlighted the substantial economic burden of CHE but noted that current cost estimates may be underestimated due to limited data on absenteeism and job loss.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic hand eczema in Europe, Australia, New Zealand, or the Americas.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Marham-e-Akbar, a Unani medicine emollient, in treating chronic atopic dermatitis (AD) and improving patients' quality of life.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant improvements in subjective symptoms (itching, scaling, erythema) and objective measures (SCORAD, DLQI) with p<0.001, indicating Marham-e-Akbar effectively ameliorated chronic AD and enhanced patients' quality of life.
population_specificity: 30 participants aged 18-65 years with chronic AD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review existing and emerging treatments for atopic dermatitis, focusing on nanotechnology-based topical therapeutics to improve drug delivery and reduce adverse effects.
results_summary: The abstract highlights the challenges of current topical treatments for atopic dermatitis, such as limited skin penetration and systemic absorption, and suggests nanotechnology-based approaches may enhance drug delivery and efficacy while minimizing side effects. It also summarizes recent patents and clinical advancements in this area.
population_specificity: Individuals with atopic dermatitis (general population, no specific subgroup mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether adding oral fexofenadine to topical treatment (including emollients) improved outcomes in atopic dermatitis compared to topical treatment alone.
results_summary: The study found no significant clinical difference between groups using emollients with or without fexofenadine, but fexofenadine reduced serum IL-31 levels.
population_specificity: 50 patients with mild to moderate atopic dermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether early, regular use of emollients prevents atopic dermatitis (AD) in high-risk infants.
results_summary: Two large RCTs found no evidence that emollients prevent AD in high-risk infants, while smaller studies produced inconclusive results. Clinicians are advised not to recommend emollients for AD prevention but may suggest safe infant skin care practices.
population_specificity: High-risk infants (those with a predisposition to developing atopic dermatitis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize available data on the mechanisms, diagnosis, and treatment options for atopic dermatitis (AD) during pregnancy, with a focus on the safety and efficacy of emollients as a foundational therapy.
results_summary: The study found that emollients form the basis of therapy for AD during pregnancy, with topical corticosteroids, calcineurin inhibitors, and ultraviolet therapy also considered safe options. Systemic therapy with cyclosporin A is possible, but safety data on newer biologics are limited.
population_specificity: Pregnant women with atopic dermatitis (either de novo, recurrent, or exacerbated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the barrier-strengthening properties of three different emollient creams (urea-glycerol cream, glycerol cream, and paraffin cream) against a no-treatment control in adults with atopic dermatitis.
results_summary: Urea-glycerol cream (UGC) significantly improved the skin's barrier, reduced irritation, and increased natural moisturizing factor levels, outperforming glycerol cream (GC) and paraffin cream (PC), which had minimal or no effect. The study concluded that not all emollients are equally effective, with UGC showing the most promise for long-term AD control.
population_specificity: Adults with atopic dermatitis (AD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the efficacy and safety of oral alitretinoin for treating chronic hand eczema (CHE) in patients unresponsive to standard treatments.
results_summary: The study found that alitretinoin effectively improved both objective and subjective clinical signs of CHE, significantly enhancing patients' quality of life. However, caution is advised for patients with certain chronic conditions or childbearing potential.
population_specificity: Patients with severe CHE refractory to potent topical corticosteroids.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of topical emollients in reducing radiation-induced skin reactions (RISR) in patients undergoing radiotherapy.
results_summary: The study found insufficient evidence to support the use of topical emollients for reducing RISRs, indicating they are not efficacious in this context.
population_specificity: Patients receiving radiotherapy, particularly those at high risk of radiation-induced skin reactions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the socio-economic and psychological burden of ARCI on family caregivers, including the impact of daily emollient use as part of disease management.
results_summary: The study found that ARCI imposes a significant burden on family caregivers, particularly in terms of time for care, extra housework, and household expenditure. Higher disease severity correlated with greater family burden, but the abstract does not specifically evaluate emollient efficacy.
population_specificity: Pediatric and adult patients with autosomal recessive congenital ichthyoses (ARCI) and their family caregivers in Italy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the psychosocial and emotional burden of Atopic Dermatitis (AD) and review treatment options, including emollients, for symptom management.
results_summary: The study highlights emollients as a recommended first-line treatment for mild AD symptoms, emphasizing their role in basic skin care maintenance and trigger avoidance. However, it does not provide specific efficacy data for emollients compared to other treatments like Dupilumab or phototherapy.
population_specificity: Pediatric and adult populations with Atopic Dermatitis (AD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare patients' and dermatologists' viewpoints on the impact of atopic dermatitis uncontrolled by topical corticosteroids, including perceptions of emollients.
results_summary: Patients and dermatologists agreed on the safety of emollients but had divergent views on treatment efficacy and the condition's impact on professional life.
population_specificity: 348 adult patients with atopic dermatitis and 150 dermatologists.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize changes in the skin microbiome during treatment for atopic dermatitis (AD), comparing standard treatment with emollients and topical corticosteroids to standard treatment with the addition of dilute bleach baths.
results_summary: The study found clear differences in the skin microbiome between healthy controls and AD patients, which diminished with treatment. After three months, the addition of dilute bleach baths to standard treatment significantly decreased the relative abundance of Staphylococcus aureus.
population_specificity: Children with moderate-to-severe AD and healthy children.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the role of ceramide abnormalities in atopic dermatitis (AD) and discuss the therapeutic potential of ceramide-dominant emollients for barrier repair in AD.
results_summary: The study found that ceramide-dominant emollients have beneficial effects on skin barrier function and are approved as adjunctive therapy for AD. The abstract highlights the involvement of ceramide abnormalities in AD pathogenesis but notes the mechanism is not fully understood.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis (AD).

study_goal: To determine if emollients used during infancy can prevent atopic dermatitis (AD) in high-risk neonates in a tropical climate and evaluate potential adverse cutaneous eruptions.
results_summary: The emollient group showed a significant reduction in AD incidence and severity, but experienced more cutaneous eruptions like miliaria and suspected infections. Adherence to emollient application influenced outcomes, with lower adherence associated with fewer AD cases.
population_specificity: High-risk neonates in a tropical climate.
effective_dosage: Applied "as needed" based on environmental factors and skin dryness.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of prophylactic skin emollients in preventing atopic dermatitis (AD) and their potential impact on allergic diseases via the gut-skin axis.
results_summary: The study found that prophylactic skin emollients did not consistently protect against AD, though dietary changes showed some evidence of alleviating AD and airway inflammation.
population_specificity: Not specified (general context of allergic disease prevention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the current state of nanocarrier-mediated topical delivery of corticosteroids, including emollients, for managing atopic dermatitis and psoriasis.
results_summary: The study highlights that emollients, combined with topical corticosteroids, are widely used for symptom management in atopic dermatitis and psoriasis. Novel nanoformulations have been developed to address limitations like low drug permeation and retention in conventional therapy.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis and psoriasis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the prevalence of diabetic foot ulcers (DFU) and identify factors associated with their occurrence, including the use of emollients.
results_summary: The study found that the use of emollients was associated with a significantly reduced likelihood of developing DFU (OR = 0.097; p < 0.001). No adverse effects or safety concerns related to emollients were reported.
population_specificity: 229 adult diabetic inpatients from seven hospitals in Manaus, Amazonas State, Brazil.

study_goal: To review existing literature examining the management of pediatric AD by PCPs, including the use of emollients.
results_summary: PCPs commonly recommended emollients for pediatric AD, though this practice was not universal. Data characterizing nonmedication management, including emollient use, were limited.
population_specificity: Children with eczema/atopic dermatitis (AD) managed by primary care providers (PCPs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of emollients in preventing eczema and managing its symptoms, based on recent evidence.
results_summary: The study found that emollients from birth do not prevent eczema and may increase risks such as skin infections and food allergy. Large trials contradicted earlier promising pilot studies, showing no benefit for eczema patients.
population_specificity: Infants from birth and eczema patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients in restoring the skin barrier and reducing inflammation in contact dermatitis.
results_summary: Emollients were identified as one of the treatments to restore the skin barrier and reduce inflammation in contact dermatitis, alongside other therapies like corticosteroids and antihistamines. The abstract highlights their inclusion in a multi-treatment approach but does not specify standalone efficacy.
population_specificity: Patients with contact dermatitis, including occupational, hand, and facial dermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of emollients in treating atopic eczema (AE) and determine if any specific emollients offer superior benefits compared to standard treatments.
results_summary: The study found a lack of good-quality trials comparing emollients with topical corticosteroids (TCS), the standard of care for AE. Large, well-designed RCTs are needed to assess whether specific emollients provide superior benefits.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic eczema (AE).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a 2% simvastatin/2% cholesterol cream versus bland emollients on lesion number, erythema, scale, and patient-reported disease activity in DSAP patients.
results_summary: The study found that topical simvastatin-cholesterol cream improved lesion number, erythema, and scale compared to emollients, with patient-reported disease activity also showing improvement. However, emollients served as the control and were not the primary focus of efficacy evaluation.
population_specificity: Eight patients (median age 65 years) with disseminated superficial actinic porokeratosis (DSAP).
effective_dosage: Bland emollients (unspecified dosage, applied twice daily).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe treatment patterns, including emollient use, in pediatric atopic dermatitis (AD) patients.
results_summary: Emollients were the most commonly used treatment (55.1%) among pediatric AD patients, but the study did not specifically evaluate their efficacy compared to other treatments. The abstract highlights undertreatment in severe AD cases but does not provide detailed outcomes for emollient use.
population_specificity: 867 pediatric patients (aged ≤16 years, mean age 5.9 years) with doctor-confirmed AD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review descriptive studies on ciprofloxacin-induced cutaneous adverse drug reactions (CADRs) and assess the role of emollients in their management.
results_summary: The study found that emollients, along with oral or topical glucocorticoids and topical moisturizers, were recommended for supportive management of CIPRO-induced CADRs. The most common CADRs included toxic epidermal necrolysis, Stevens-Johnson syndrome, and fixed drug eruptions.
population_specificity: Patients experiencing CIPRO-induced cutaneous adverse drug reactions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a novel emollient plus cream (EC) on skin barrier recovery in vitro and in patients with mild-to-moderate atopic dermatitis (AD).
results_summary: EC treatment significantly improved epidermal thickness, lipid content, and skin hydration, while reducing vascularization and keratin-16 expression, suggesting skin barrier repair and immune response regulation. In patients, EC decreased epidermal thickness and blood vessel count while improving hydration after 2 months.
population_specificity: Patients with mild-to-moderate atopic dermatitis in clinical remission.
effective_dosage: Applied once daily (undiluted or diluted 1:1 with water in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the causes and treatments of eczematous drug eruptions, including the role of emollients in managing these reactions.
results_summary: The study found that emollients, along with topical corticosteroids and oral antihistamines, are effective in treating most eczematous drug eruptions. The abstract highlights their use as part of a standard treatment approach without specifying detailed outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with eczematous drug eruptions, including those on biologic therapies, targeted cancer treatments, antiviral agents, and cardiovascular medications.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether skincare interventions, primarily emollients, could prevent eczema or food allergy in infants.
results_summary: The study found that regular emollients during infancy probably do not prevent eczema and may increase the risk of local skin infections. No significant effect on food allergy risk was observed.
population_specificity: Term infants under 1 year of age with healthy skin.
effective_dosage: Applied for the first 3-12 months (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether skin care interventions like emollients in infancy could prevent eczema and food allergy, and to identify factors influencing treatment benefit or harm.
results_summary: Emollients during infancy probably do not reduce eczema risk and may increase skin infection risk. Effects on food allergy are uncertain, with very low-certainty evidence.
population_specificity: Healthy term infants (0-12 months) without pre-existing eczema, food allergy, or other skin conditions, including high-risk infants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of different hand hygiene agents, including emollient-containing alcohol hand sanitizer, in preventing neonatal infections in community and health facility settings.
results_summary: The study found very low-certainty evidence regarding the efficacy of emollient-containing alcohol hand sanitizer compared to 2% chlorhexidine gluconate, with no clear superiority demonstrated. Adverse effects were minimal, but the evidence was highly uncertain.
population_specificity: Neonates, mothers, caregivers, and healthcare workers in community and health facility settings.
effective_dosage: 61% alcohol with emollients (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the real-world treatment patterns and long-term burden of atopic dermatitis (AD) in adults using systemic therapy, including emollients.
results_summary: The study found that adults with moderate-to-severe AD had a high disease burden despite continuous use of topical drugs, emollients, and systemic therapies, with significant impacts on quality of life and mental health.
population_specificity: Adults with moderate-to-severe atopic dermatitis (average age 37 years, 43% female) from 10 European countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of emollients in managing eczema in elderly patients, considering safety and efficacy alongside other treatment options.
results_summary: Emollients were found to be helpful in managing eczema in the elderly, though the abstract highlights potential adverse effects of alternative treatments like local corticosteroids. No specific adverse effects of emollients were mentioned.
population_specificity: Elderly patients with eczema, including those with comorbidities like leg ulcers or drug-induced eczematous eruptions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review best practices for managing oral health care in inherited EB, including the use of nonadhesive wound care products and emollients to reduce friction during patient care.
results_summary: The study highlighted the importance of using emollients to reduce friction during dental care for EB patients, emphasizing patient-clinician partnership and follow-up appointments. Guidance on emollient use was provided as part of broader oral health management.
population_specificity: Patients with inherited epidermolysis bullosa (EB), including subtypes like recessive dystrophic EB (RDEB).

study_goal: The researchers sought to determine the efficacy of different bathing/showering frequencies at improving atopic dermatitis (AD) severity.
results_summary: The study found that bathing/showering ≥7 times per week versus <7 times per week did not show significant differences in AD severity improvement. All included studies demonstrated numerically reduced AD severity compared to baseline.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis (AD).
effective_dosage: Not specified (focus was on bathing/showering frequency).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the prevalence and diagnostic challenges of allergic contact dermatitis (ACD) in pediatric populations, including the role of emollients as common allergens.
results_summary: The abstract identifies emollients as one of the top allergens in pediatric ACD cases, emphasizing the need for accurate diagnosis to prevent persistent symptoms and quality-of-life impacts.
population_specificity: Pediatric populations (children and adolescents) with suspected allergic contact dermatitis.
